div.stage: Enter Harliquin with Fetherfool's Cloaths on his Shoulder, leading him halting by one hand, Blunt (drunk) by the other by dark— Fetherfool bloody, his Coat put over his Shoulders.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Peano, Peano, Seignior, gently good Edward—for I'le not halt before a Cripple; I have lost a great part of my agil faculties.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Ah—see the inconstancy of fickle fortune, Nicholas— a Man to day, and beaten to morrow: but take comfort, there's many a proper fellow has been robb'd and beaten on this Highway of Whoring.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Ay Ned, thou speak'st by woful experience—but that I should miscarry after thy wholsome documents; but we are all Mortal as thou say'st, Ned—would I had never crost the Ferry from Croydon: a few such Nights as these wou'd learn a Man experience enough to be a Wizard, if he have but the ill luck to escape hanging.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: 'Dshartlikins, I wonder in what Country our kinder Stars rule in England, plunder'd, sequester'd, imprison'd and banish'd; in France starv'd, walking like the Sign of the Naked Boy, with Plimouth Cloaks in our hands: in Italy and Spain robb'd, beaten and thrown out at Windows.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Well—how happy am I—in having so true a friend to condole me in affliction— Weeps. I am oblig'd to Seignior Harliquin too, for bringing me hither to the Mountebank's, where I shall not only conceal this Catastrophe from those fortunate Rogues our Comrades, but procure a little Album Grecum for my Backside, come, Seignior, my Cloaths—but Seignior—un Portavera Poco palauea. Dresses himself.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Seignior.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Em Poco, em Poco, Seignior.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Per quelq arts, Did your Seigniorship escape Cudgeling?

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Transformatio—Whe, wer't thou not born a Man?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: No, Seignior, un vieule Famme.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: How, born an old Woman?

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Good Lord! born an old Woman! and so by transformation became invulnerable.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Ay—in—invulnerable—what would I give to be invulnerable: and Egad I am almost weary of being a Man, and subject to beating: wou'd I were a Woman, a Man has but an ill time on't: if he has a mind to a Wench, the making Love is so plaguy tedious—then paying is to my Soul insupportable, but to be a Woman, to be Courted with presents, and have both the pleasure and the profit—to be without a Beard, and sing a fine treble—and squeak if the Men but kiss me—'twere fine—and what's better, I am sure never to be beaten again.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Pox on't, do not use an old friend so scurvily; consider the misery thou't indure to have the heart and mind of a Jilting Whore possess thee: what a fit of the Devil must he suffer who Acts her part from fourteen to fourscore, no, 'tis resolv'd thou remain Nicholas Fetherfool still, shalt marry the Monster, and laugh at Fortune.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: 'Tis true, should I turn Whore to the disgrace of my Family—what wou'd the World say, Who wou'd have thought it, cries one; I cou'd never have believ'd, cries another; no, as thou say'st: I'le remain as I am—marry and live honestly.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Well resolv'd, I'le leave you, for I was just going to Serenade my Fayrie Queen, when I met thee at the Door—some deeds of Gallantry must be perform'd, Seignior, Bonus Nochus.

div.stage: Ex. Blunt.
Enter Shift with Light.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Hah, a Light, undone!

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Patientia, Patientia, Seignior.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Where the Devil can this Rogue Hunt be; Just now all things are ready for marrying these two Monsters: they wait, the House is husht, and in the lucky minute to have him out of the way, sure the Devil owes me a spight.

div.stage: Runs against Harliquin, puts out his Candle.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: 'Tis Harliquin, Pox on't, is't you?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Peace, here's Fetherfool, I'le secure him, whil'st you go about your affair. Ex. Shift.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Oh, I hear a noise, dear Harliquin secure me, if I am discover'd I am undone—hold, hold—here's a Door—

div.stage: They both go in.

div.head: SCENE changes to a Chamber, discovers the She-Giant asleep in a great great Chair.
div.stage: Enter Fetherfool and Harliquin.
div.p: —hah—my Lady Monster, have I to avoid Scylla run upon Caribdis—hah she sleeps; now wou'd some magnanimous Lover make good use of this opportunity, take fortune by the fore-lock, put her to't, and make sure work—but Egad he must have a better heart, or a better Mistriss than I.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Try your strength, I'le be civil and leave you.

div.stage: In Italian he still speaks.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Excuse me, Seignior, I should crackle like a wicker Bottle in her Arms—no, Seignior, there's no venturing without a grate between us; the Devil wou'd not give her due Benevolence—no, when I'm marry'd, I'le e'ne show her a fair pair of Heels, her Portion will pay postage—but what if the Giant should carry her, that's to be fear'd, then I have cock'd and drest, and feed and ventur'd all this while for nothing.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Faith, Seignior, if I were you, I wou'd make sure of something, see how rich she is in Jems.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Right, as thou say'st, I ought to make sure of something, and she is rich in Jems: How amiable looks that Neck with that delicious row of Pearls about it.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: She sleeps.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Ay, she sleeps as 'twere her last. What if I made bold to unrig her? so if I miss the Lady, I have at least my charges paid, what vigorous Lover can resist her Charms—
sp.stage: Looks on her.
sp.p: but shou'd she wake and miss it, and find it about me, I shou'd be hang'd— Turns away.

—so then, I lose my Lady too—but flesh and blood cannot resist—What if I left the Town? then I lose my Lady still, and who wou'd lose a Hog for the rest of the Proverb—and yet a Bird in hand, friend Nicholas—yet sweet meat may have sour sauce—and yet refuse when fortune offers—yet honesty's a Jewel
—but a Pox upon Pride when folks go naked—

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Well said. Incouraging him by signs.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Ay—I'le do't—but what remedy now against discovery and restitution—

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, take no care, you shall—swallow 'em.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: How, swallow 'em, I shall ne're be able to do't.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: I'le show you, Seignior, 'tis easie.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: 'Gad that may be, 'twere excellent if I cou'd do't; but first—by your leave. Ʋnties the Necklace, breaks the string, and Harl. swallows one to show him.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Look ye, that's all—

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Seignior, an you be so nimble, I shall pay dear for my Learning—let me see—friend Nicholas, thou hast swallow'd many a Pill for the Disease of the Body, let's see what thou canst perform for that of the Purse. Swallows 'em.
—so—a comfortable business this—three or four thousand pound in Cordial Pearl: 'Sbud Mark Anthony was never so treated by his Egyptian Crocodile—hah, what noise is that?

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Operator, Operator, Seignior.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: How, an Operator, whe what the Devil makes he here? some Plot upon my Ladies Chastity; were I given to be Jealous now, danger wou'd insue—oh, he's entring, I wou'd not be seen for all the World: oh some place of refuge—

div.stage: Looking about.

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: I know of none.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Hah, what's this—a Clock-Case—

sp.speaker: Harl.
sp.p: Good, good—look you, Sir, do you do thus, and 'tis impossible to discover ye.

div.stage: Goes into the Case and shows him how to stand; then Fether. goes in, pulls off his Periwig, his Head out turning for the Minutes o'th' top: his Hand out, and his Finger pointing to a Figure.
Enter Shift and Hunt.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Oh Heaven, he's here.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p:
See where she sleeps; get you about your business, see your own little Marmoset and the Priest be ready, that we may Marry and Consummate before day: and in the morning our
friends shall see us abed together, give us the good morrow, and the work's done. Ex. Hunt.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Oh Traytor to my Bed, what a Hellish Plot's here discover'd. Shift wakes the Giant.

sp.speaker: Gia.
sp.p: Oh are you come my sweetest?

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Hah, the Mistriss of my Bosom false too; ah, who wou'd trust faithless Beauty—oh that I durst speak—

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Come let's away, your Uncle and the rest of the House are fast asleep, let's away e're the two fools, Blunt and Fetherfool, arrive.

sp.speaker: Gia.
sp.p: Hang 'em Pigeon-hearted slaves—

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: A Clock— let's see what hour 'tis—
sp.stage: Lifts up the light to see, Feth. blows it out.
sp.p: —how! betray'd—I'le kill the Villain. Draws.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Say you so, then 'tis time for me to uncase.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Have you your Lovers hid?

div.stage: Gets out all groping in the dark, Feth. gets the Giant by the Hand.

sp.speaker: Gia.
sp.p: Softly or we're undone; give me your hand and be undeceiv'd.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: 'Tis she, now shall I be reveng'd. Leads her out.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: What gone! Death, has this Monster got the Arts of Woman. Harl. meets him in the dark and playstricks with him.

div.stage: Ex. all.
Enter Willmore and La Nuche by dark.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Now we are safe and free let's in my Soul, and gratefully first Sacrifice to Love, then to the Gods of Mirth and Wine, my dear. Ex. passing over the Stage.

div.stage: Enter Blunt with Petronella, imbracing her, his Sword in his hand, and a Box of Jewels.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I was damnably afraid I was pursu'd. Aside.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Something in the fray I've got, pray Heaven it prove a Prize, after my cursed ill luck of losing my Lady Dwarf: Why do you tremble fair one?—you're in the hands of an honest Gentleman, Adshartlikins.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, just as I approacht Seignior Doctor's Door, to have my self surrounded with naked Weapons, then to drop with the fear my Casket of Jewels, which had not you by chance stumbled on and taken up, I had lost a hundred thousand Crowns with it.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Ha um— a hundred thousand Crowns—a pretty trifling sum—I'le marry her out of hand.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: This is an English-man, of a dull honest Nation, and might be manag'd to advantage, were but I transform'd now.
sp.stage: Aside.
sp.p: I hope you are a Man of Honour, Sir, I am a Virgin, fled from the rage of an incens'd Brother; cou'd you but secure me with my Treasure, I wou'd be devoted yours.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Secure thee, by this light, sweet Soul, I'le marry thee: —Belluile's Lady ran just so away with him—this must be a Prize— Aside.
but hark—prithee, my Dear, step in a little, I'le keep my good fortune to my self.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: See what trust I repose in your hands, those Jewels, Sir.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: So—there can be no Jilting here, I am secur'd from being couzen'd however. Ex. Pet.

div.stage: Enter Fetherfool.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: A Pox on all fools, I say, and a double Pox on all fighting fools; just when I had miraculously got my Monster by a mistake in the dark, convey'd her out, and within a moment of marrying her, to have my friend set upon me and occasion my losing her, was a Catastrophe which none but thy termagant Courage (which never did any man good) cou'd have procur'd.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: 'Dshartlikins I cou'd kill my self—

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: To fight away a couple of such hopeful Monsters, and two Millions—'owns, was ever Valour so improvident?

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Your fighting made me mistake—for who the Pox wou'd have look'd for Nicholas Fetherfool in the person of a Hero.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Fight, 'Sbud a Million of Money wou'd have provok'd a Bully; besides, I took you for the damn'd Rogue my Rival.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p:
Just as I had finish'd my Serenade, and had put up my Pipes to be gone, out-stalk'd me your two-handed Lady, with a Man at her Girdle like a bunch of Keys, whom I taking for nothing
less than some one who had some foul design upon the Gentlewoman, like a true Knight Errant, did my best to rescue her.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I feel you did, a Pox of your heavy hand.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: So whil'st we two were lovingly cuffing each other, comes the Rival, I suppose, and carry's off the Prize.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Who must be Seignior Lucifer himself, he cou'd never have Vanisht with that Celerity else with such a carriage—but come, all we have to do is to raise the Mountebank and the Guardian, pursue the Rogues, have 'em hang'd by Law for a Rape and Theft, and then we stand fair again.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Faith, you may if you please, but fortune has provided otherwise for me. Aside. Ex. Blu. and Feth.

div.stage: Enter Beaumond and Ariadne.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sure none lives here, or Thieves are broken in, the Doors are all left open.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Pray Heaven this stranger prove but honest now.

div.stage: Aside.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Now my dear Creature every thing conspires to make us happy, let us not defer it.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Hold, dear Captain, I yield but on conditions, which are these—I give you up a Maid of Youth and Beauty, ten thousand Pound in ready Jewels here—three times the value in Estate to come, of which here be the Writings, you delivering me a handsom proper fellow, heart-whole and sound, that's all—your Name I ask not till the Priest declare it, who is to seal the bargain: I cannot deceive, for I let you know I am Daughter-in-law to the English Ambassador.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: How vain is all Man's industry and care
To make him accomplish'd;
When the gay fluttering fool,
Or the half-witted rough unmanner'd brute, Aside.
Who in plain terms comes right down to the business,
Out-Rivals him in all his Love and Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: —Methinks you cool upon't, Captain.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Yes, Ariadne—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Oh what a world of time have I mispent for want of being a Blockhead—'Sdeath and Hell,
sp.l: Wou'd I had been some brawny ruffling fool,
Some forward impudent unthinking sloven,
A Womans tool; for all besides unmanageable.
—Come, swear that all this while you thought 'twas I:
The Devil has taught ye tricks to bring your falshood off.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Know 'twas you? no, faith, I took you for as errant a right-down Captain as ever Woman wisht for: and 'twas uncivil Egad to undeceive me, I tell you that now.

div.stage: Enter Willmore and La Nuche by dark,

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Thou art all Charms, a Heaven of sweets all over, plump smooth round Limbs, small rising Breasts, a Bosom soft and panting—I long to wound each sense: Lights there—who waits— there yet remains a Pleasure unpossest, the sight of that dear face. —Lights there—where are my Vermin? Ex. Will.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: My Captain with a Woman—and is it so—

div.stage: Enter Will. with Lights, sees Aria. and goes to her.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: By Heaven a glorious Beauty! now a blessing on thee for showing me so dear a face—come, Child, let's retire, and begin where we left off.

sp.speaker: La Nu.
sp.p: A Woman!

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Where we left off, pray, where was that good Captain?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Within upon the Bed, Child—come—I'le show thee—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Hold, Sir.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Beaumond come fit to celebrate my happiness: ah such a Woman friend!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Do ye know her?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: All ore, to be the softest sweetest Creature—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I mean, do ye know who she is?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Nor care; 'tis the last Question I ever ask a fine Woman.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: And you are sure you are thus well acquainted.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p:
I cannot boast of much acquaintance—but I have pluckt a Rose from her Bosom—or so—and given it her again
—we've past the hour of the Berjere together, that's all—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: And do you know—this Lady is my—Wife?

div.stage: Draw.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Hah! hum, hum, hum, hum—

div.stage: Turns and sings, sees La Nuche, and returns quick with an uneasie Grimace.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Did you not hear me—Draw.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Draw, Sir—what—on my friend.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: On your Cuckold, Sir, for so you've doubly made me: Draw, or I'le kill thee— Passes at him, he fences with his Hat, La Nu. holds Beau.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Hold, prithee hold—

sp.speaker: La Nu.
sp.p: Put up your Sword, this Lady's innocent, at least in what concerns this Evenings business: I own—with Pride I own I am the Woman that pleas'd so well to Night.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: La Nuche! kind Soul to bring me off with so handsom a lie: how lucky 'twas she happen'd to be here.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: False as thou art, why shou'd I credit thee?

sp.speaker: La Nu.
sp.p: By Heav'n, 'tis true, I will not lose the glory on't.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Oh the dear Perjur'd Creature, how I Love thee for this dear lying Vertue—harkye, Child, hast thou nothing to say for thy self to help us out withal?— To Aria. aside.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: I! I renounce ye—false Man.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I know she's innocent of this, for which I owe no thanks to either of you, but to my self who mistook her in the dark.

sp.speaker: La Nu.
sp.p: And you it seems mistook me for this Lady; I favour'd your design to gain your heart, for I was told, that if this Night I lost you, I shou'd never regain you: now I am yours, and o're the habitable World will follow you, and live and starve by turns as fortune pleases.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Nay, by this light, Child, I knew when once thou'dst try'd me, thou'dst ne'r part with me—give me thy hand, no poverty shall part us. Kisses her.
—so—now here's a bargain made without the formal foppery of Marriage.

sp.speaker: La Nu.
sp.p: Nay, faith Captain, she that will not take thy word as soon as the Parsons of the Parish deserves not the blessing.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Thou art reform'd, and I adore the change.

div.stage: Enter the Guardian, Blunt and Fetherfool.

sp.speaker: Guar.
sp.p: My Nieces stoln, and by a couple of the Seigniors Men! the Seignior fled too, undone, undone.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Hah, now's my Cue; I must finish this Jest. Goes out.

div.stage: Enter Shift and Giant, Hunt and Dwarf.

sp.speaker: Guar.
sp.p: Oh impudence, my Nieces, and the Villains with 'em; I charge ye Gentlemen to lay hold on 'em.

sp.speaker: Dwa.
sp.p: For what, good Uncle, for being so couragious to marry us.

sp.speaker: Guar.
sp.p: How, married to Rogues, Rascals, John Potages!

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Who the Devil wou'd have look'd for Jilting in such Hobgoblins?

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: And hast thou deceiv'd me, thou foul filthy Synagogue.

div.stage: Enter Willmore like a Mountebank as before.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: The Mountebank! oh thou cheating Quack, thou sophisticated adulterated Villain.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Thou couzening, lying, fortune-telling, fee-taking Rascal.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Thou Jugling, Conjuring, Canting Rogue!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: What's the matter, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Hast thou the impudence to ask who took my money to marry me to this ill-favour'd Baboon.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: And me to this foul filthy o're-grown Chronacle.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: And hast suffered Rogues, thy Servants, to marry 'em: Sirra, I will beat thee past Cure of all thy hard-nam'd Drugs, thy Guzman Medicines.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Nay, I'le Peach him in the Inquisition for a Wizard, and have him hang'd for a Witch.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Sir, we are Gentlemen, and you shall have the thirds of their Portion, what wou'd you more. Aside to the Guar.
Look ye, Sir. Pulls off their Disguise.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Shift! we are betray'd! all will out to the Captain.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p:
He shall know no more of it than he does already for me,
Gentlemen. Pulls of his Disguise.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Ay, ay, 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Draw, Sir—you know me—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: —For one that 'tis impossible to couzen.

div.stage: All Laugh.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Have a care, Sir, we are all for the Captain.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: As for that, Sir, we fear ye not, de see, were you Hercules and all his Mermidons. Draws, but gets behind.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Fools, put up your Swords, fools, and do not publish the Jest; your money you shall have again, on condition you never pretend to be wiser than your other men, but modestly believe you may be couzen'd as well as your Neighbours.

div.stage: The Guardian talking with Hunt and Shift and Giant this while.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: La you, Ned, why shou'd friends fall out?

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Couzen'd, it may be not, Sir, for look ye, Sir, the Essex fool, the couzen'd dull Rogue can show moveables or so—nay, they are right too— Shows his Jewels.
This is no Naples Adventure, Gentlemen, no Copper Chains; all substantial Diamonds, Pearls and Rubies —

div.stage: Will. takes the Casket and looks in it.

sp.speaker: La Nu.
sp.p: Hah, do not I know that Casket, and those Jewels.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: How the Pox came this Rogue by these?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Hum, Edward, I confess you have redeem'd your reputation, and shall hereafter pass for a Wit—by what good fortune came you by this treasure?—what Lady?—

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Lady, Sir! alas no, I am a fool, a Country fop, an ass, I; but that you may perceive your selves mistaken, Gentlemen, this is but an earnest of what's to come, a small token of remembrance, or so—and yet I have no Charms, I; the fine Captain has all the Wit and Beauty— but thou'rt my friend, and I'le impart.

div.stage: Brings out Petronella Veil'd.
Enter Aurelia and Sancho.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Hither we trac'd her, and see she's yonder.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Sir, in the Kings Name lay hold of this old cheat; she has this Night robb'd our Patrona of a hundred thousand Crowns in Money and Jewels.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Hah! Gets from her.

sp.speaker: La Nu.
sp.p: You are mistaken, friend Sancho, she only seiz'd 'em for my use, and has deliver'd 'em in trust to my friend the Captain.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Hah, La Nuche!

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: How! couz'nd again!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Look ye, Sir, she's so Beautiful, you need no Portion, that alone's sufficient for a Wit.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Much good may do you with your rich Lady, Edward.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: Death, this fool laugh at me too—well, I am an errant right-down Logerhead, a dull conceited couzen'd silly fool, and he that ever takes me for any other, 'Dshartlikins, I'le beat him: I forgive you all, and will henceforth be good natur'd: wo't borrow any money, Pox on't, I'le lend as far as e're 'twill go, for I am now reclaim'd.

sp.speaker: Guar.
sp.p: Here is a Necklace of Pearl lost, which, Sir, I lay to your Charge. To Fetherfool.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Hum, I was bewitcht I did not rub off with it when it was mine—who I, if e're I saw a Necklace of Pearl, I wish 'twere in my Belly.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.p: How, a Necklace, unconscionable Rogue, not to let me share, well there is no friendship in this World: I hope they'l hang him.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: He'l ne'r confess without the Rack—come, we'l toss him in a Blanket.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Hah, toss me in a Blanket, that will turn my Stomach most villainously, and I shall disimbogue and discover all.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Come, come, the Blanket. They lay hold of him.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Hold, hold, I do confess, I do confess—

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Restore, and have your Pardon.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: That is not in Nature at present, for Gentlemen, I have eat 'em.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, I'le dissect ye. Goes to Draw.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Let me redeem him; here Boy, take him to my Chamber, and let the Doctor Glyster him soundly, and I'le warrant you your Pearl again.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: If this be the end of Travelling, I'le e'ne to old England again, take the Covenant, get a Sequestrators place, grow rich, and defie all Cavaliering.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: 'Tis Morning, let's home, Ariadne, and try, if possible, to love so well to be content to marry; if we find that amendment in our hearts, to say we dare believe and trust each other, then let it be a match.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: You have a hankering after Marriage still, but I am for Love and Gallantry.

lg.l: So tho by several ways we gain our End,
Love still, like Death, does to one Center tend.
